Liquor Stores and Low-Income Shoppers
by Kristin Wiederholt
December 16, 2005
Listen
Day to Day
Add to Playlist Download text size A A A December 16, 2005 Vandalism and arson at Arab-American owned liquor stores in Oakland, Calif., highlight prejudices and resentments. Kristin Wiederholt of member station KALW reports that many resent having to rely on corner liquor stores for groceries.
Copyright©2005 National Public Radio. For personal, noncommercial use only. See Terms of Use. For other uses, prior permission required.
ALEX CHADWICK, host:
This is DAY TO DAY. I'm Alex Chadwick.
Coming up, a new documentary where boy meets boy and then girl meets boys, and can the three live happily every after?
First, this. Across the bay from San Francisco in Oakland, in some of the city's poor neighborhoods, there's a battle under way between liquor store owners, most of whom are Arab-Americans, and local residents and city officials who complain the liquor stores are contributing to squalor. From member station KALW in San Francisco, Kristin Wiederholt reports.
KRISTIN WIEDERHOLT reporting:
Jax Liquor is typical inner city corner store in East Oakland. It hums with the sound of refrigerators and freezers that line two walls inside. They're full of soft drinks, juice, water and alcohol. Mohamed Saleh Mohamed is filling in behind the counter today for his brother. He believes Oakland liquor stores are under siege these days and the scapegoat for all inner-city problems.
Mr. MOHAMED SALEH MOHAMED (Store Clerk): If you have a killing down the street a block away, they will blame the liquor store. If you have a car accident, you know, where a man is drunk, you would say, `That's the liquor store.' I mean, everything relates to the liquor store.
WIEDERHOLT: In the first 20 minutes after opening today, most of the customers are African-American and roughly half of them buy alcohol. Mohamed, who's president of the Yemeni-American Grocers Association, says merchants are running legitimate businesses and only selling what people want to buy.
Mr. MOHAMED: If you want bananas every day and say, `I want bananas,' I will bring bananas. But if you come in and ask for half pint of liquor or a can of malt liquor, I have to provide you that service. I'm obligated because you're not going to come back if I don't have that product. So you dictate what I sell. So the community dictate what I sell.
WIEDERHOLT: At least some in the community agree. African-American resident Calvin Neal(ph) likes the convenience of corner stores.
Mr. CALVIN NEAL (Corner Store Customer): But I don't see the stores as being a problem. I mean, you know, hey, a lot to times they save us a trip to the grocery store or something. You know what I mean?
WIEDERHOLT: Yet many locals of all ethnicities do see them as a problem. There are 350 liquor stores in Oakland with the highest concentration in low-income neighborhoods where there are a few, if any, grocery stores. Residents claim problem stores cause litter, loitering, prostitution, drug dealing and crime. Some have taken to violence to deal with the issue. Three liquor stores have been vandalized in the last few months and four African-American men have been charged with felony vandalism and hate crimes. Not far away, in a grittier section of East Oakland, the streets are lined with trash.
Mr. LEON PAULOS: Just look around you, and this is a clean day.
WIEDERHOLT: Leon Paulos and his wife have joined with neighbors and are actively trying to get a corner liquor store on their block to clean up.
Mr. PAULOS: On this street, on this wide side of East 15th Street, any time of day, you'll see a cluster of people just sitting around on old milk crates drinking out of brown paper bags.
WIEDERHOLT: They say besides all the trash, the type of people the liquor store attracts makes the neighborhood feel unsafe. Ignacio de la Fuente, president of the Oakland City Council, says cracking down on problem liquor stores is a priority.
Mr. IGNACIO DE LA FUENTE (President, Oakland City Council): The fact is that Oakland has an unfair number of liquor stores, and I think, at no question about it, it affects people of color disproportionately, all of us. And I think that that's why we are working so hard to change that.
WIEDERHOLT: Controlling liquor stores is tricky because liquor licenses are issued by the state, not the city. In the past two years, Oakland has begun enforcing an innovative ordinance to put pressure on liquor stores. The ordinance sets a series of operating standards, including having appropriate outside lighting and eliminating trash in the doorway and adjacent sidewalks. Stores that don't comply face hefty fines that can put them out of business. So far, the city has forced five stores to close or stop selling liquor; dozens of others have changed their business practices. In the meantime, de la Fuente says the vandalism of Arab liquor stores is not helping the city's campaign. It sends the wrong message about racial tension in the city.
Mr. DE LA FUENTE: Oakland cannot afford this `Is he a black or brown or Middle Eastern' or anything like that. You got a good neighbor? You got a good neighbor. You have a bad neighbor? You have a bad neighbor no matter what color you are.
WIEDERHOLT: Oakland's official effort to close down or change the practices of liquor stores has been so effective it has caught the attention of other cities in California. In November, a San Francisco supervisor sponsored legislation similar to Oakland's that would give San Francisco more direct control over the liquor store business. For NPR News, I'm Kristin Wiederholt.
CHADWICK: I'm Alex Chadwick. More coming up on DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
